It was a great pleasure to talk with you during the NAEB Convention
in Philadelphia. I appreciate your sending me the list of films and
kinescopes that are available in your instructional television film
library.
I would certainly like to have the opportunity of viewing several
sample films during the next couple of months at your convenience.
The following would be of particular interest:
1. DNA Molecule and Reproduction. Philadelphia Schools
and C.B.C.
2. The Endless Adventure. Assoc. Rediffusion
3. Mine is Heavier. France
4. Kabuki. Japan
5. American History 11th Grade. MPATI.
As I mentioned during our discussion in Philadelphia, the NAEB Com¬
mittee on Instructional Television (of vh ich I am chairman) has had a
project to make available to television teachers and directors, examples
of television instruction on 16mm film or kinescope. There seems to
be a great deal of interest in having such examples available so that
directors and teachers can gather new ideas and raise the general standards
of instructional television. There is an interest furthermore in having ex¬
amples from various instructional levels - elementary, secondary, college
undergraduate and post graduate (e.g., in-service teacher training, adult
education and professional training(doctors).
